title.narrative: business forum activities and the implementation of the SESEZ Program

description.narrative: Investment Climate in Liberia is more conducive for MSMEs and changes to the reform agenda are successfully implemented. The SESEZ is supported by government stakeholders and implemented on behalf of zone tenants, investors, and laborers. The creation of domestic and regional value added-chains, especially in traditionally productive sectors including agriculture, as well as manufacturing, creates employment and skills training opportunities for Liberians across industrial and economic scales.

Project Outcomes: LBBF and Liberian Business Associations are successful advocates for MSMEs sector The SESEZ Program is allocated a physical space and the SESEZ policy agenda and infrastructure is implemented. Move-in of zone tenants
Project Outcome Indicators: (a) Increase in business associations satisfaction with LBBF support (b) Increased ownership of business associations by its members (c) Proof of business barriers removed for MSMEs in Liberia (d) Allocated space for SESEZ, and approval/buy-in for SESEZ policy agenda (e) Development of hard and soft infrastructure in the SESEZ (f) Buy-in from SESEZ investors/donors

SPARKs vision is that pro-poor sustainable economic growth is essential for creating self-reliance and through it poverty alleviation in the least developed countries and fragile states. SPARK is the sole recipient of funding for the years 2012 through 2015 under the United Entrepreneurship Coalitions Program (the “UEC Program”), which is operated by the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs (“NLMFA”) as back-donor and awards funding in the form of a so-called “MFS II grant.” SPARK has overall responsibility for achievement of UEC Program results and expenditures made from UEC Program funds. In connection with the UEC Program, SPARK has formed a consortium with other Dutch entities (the “Alliance”) to strengthen their capacity to fund activities under the UEC Program. IFC is seeking to work with the members of the Alliance in order to: (i) maximize synergy; (ii) use scale advantages; (iii) develop efficiency; and (iv) increase the effectiveness of the UEC Program.
J. SPARK and LBBF have agreed to cooperate in the further implementation of business forum activities and the implementation of the SESEZ Program, within the framework of the UEC Program, covering the period October 12, 2014 through December 31, 2015.
K. SPARK and LBBF intend to cooperate with respect to the Project by:
(i) Strengthening relevant local members of LBBF; (ii) Facilitating entrepreneurship; (iii) Creating an enabling environment for private sector development. (iv) Facilitating the further development and implementation of the SESEZ Program
Project Goals, Impact, Outcomes and Indicators
The main goals of the Project are to:
Build upon Liberias impressive investment climate improvement progress and Deepen the Liberia reform agenda to ensure continued impact of development objectives. Improve the business environment in Liberia through strategic policy reforms, and hard and soft infrastructure development. Improve the business environment in Liberia allowing for new or existing businesses to successfully start, register, grow and/or increase access to financing To develop coherent advocacy strategies that support the organization of roundtable sessions with relevant stakeholders and improve the public-private dialogue in Liberia To improve increased access to finance by supporting transparency of existing finance options and supporting consumer education of same. To address existing market gaps, facilitating domestic and regional value chain and value- added creation in traditionally productive and manufacturing sectors. To improve on the delivery and regulation of services to businesses including taxes and licensing, customs processing, immigration, and access to finance.
The LBBF seeks to strengthen the capacity of Liberias business associations in order for them to be successful advocates for the private sector but specifically SMEs. Through Its SESEZ Program, LBBF seeks to plan, design, lobby, and advocate for the implementation of an SEZ focused on social impact and the improvement of the business regulatory and investment climates.
